choices.text:
### System:
You are an AI assistant that follows instruction extremely well. Help as much as you can.

### User:
Explain origin of standard gauge for railways

### Response:


The standard gauge for railways is 1435mm, which was established in the late 19th century by the London, Midland and Scottish Railway (LMS) and the Great Western Railway (GWR). The decision to use this specific gauge was based on several factors, including the availability of materials and tools at the time, as well as the desire for consistency across different railway companies. The standard gauge also allowed for easier interchange between different lines, which helped to increase efficiency and reduce costs. Today, most modern railways around the world use the standard gauge, with only a few exceptions such as some heritage railways and foreign-owned tracks in the UK.
